abstract.p: Letter from Consumers Union counsel Frank Torres disputes David Evans's June 15 Op-Ed article on antitrust suit against MasterCard and Visa (S)

block.p: Every financial institution should be able to offer consumers a wide range of choices. Practices that keep competitors out run counter to what the law promised. One such practice -- a Visa and MasterCard bylaw that prohibits member banks in the United States from issuing competing cards -- is at the heart of the Justice Department's lawsuit against those associations (editorial, June 15).

Every financial institution should be able to offer consumers a wide range of choices. Practices that keep competitors out run counter to what the law promised. One such practice -- a Visa and MasterCard bylaw that prohibits member banks in the United States from issuing competing cards -- is at the heart of the Justice Department's lawsuit against those associations (editorial, June 15).

Is there competition because a consumer finds several card offers in the mailbox, as David Evans, a Visa consultant, argues (Op-Ed, June 14)? The number of offers alone cannot compensate for a lack of meaningful choice among credit card products and services available through a consumer's bank.

Banks should be able to offer a greater range of products from truly independent companies aggressively competing against each other. Artificial restrictions that prevent consumers from enjoying the benefits of competition should be eliminated.
FRANK TORRES Legislative Counsel Consumers Union Washington, June 15, 2000
